2019, Shannon 2004). As noted in the introduction to this paper, however, this research has tended to focus on understanding emotional support from the perspective of mothers with children with disabilities (e.g. Brotherson et al.
2010) and has paid less attention to fathersâ€™ perspectives on and needs for emotional support. Certainly, mothers are more likely than fathers to seek support in dealing with the stress, emotional intensity, and burden of parenting (Hu 2016). A Finnish study showed that fathers of children with ID use coping strategies less frequently and less positively than do mothers (Saloviita et al.
2003), and a Polish study that fathers of children with Down Syndrome are less likely than their spouses to seek emotional support from outside sources (Dabrowska and Pisula 2010). Huang et al. (2012) also found that fathersâ€™ experiences of parenting children with ID appear to differ from mothersâ€™ experiences: While mothers experience a loss of ability to control planning for the familyâ€™s future, and experience a lack of emotional regulation strategies to support their work with their children with ID, fathers experience poorer mental wellbeing, in part because of elevated stress, and poorer physical health often accompanied by chronic illness.Fathers may well be less willing than mothers to share their experiences and coping strategies with researchers (Boyd et al.
2019) but, as well, research on fathers of children with ID has tended to emphasize the negative aspects of the fathersâ€™ experiences. The literature has not yet explored the full range of perceptions that fathers have of their children with ID nor has it ventured far into exploring the emotional supports that fathers could access to help them cope with parenting challenges. Certainly, it is not clear how fathers perceive emotional support or what might encourage them to seek sources of such support (Brotherson et al.
2010). BostrÃ¶m and Broberg (2014), examining Swedish fathers of children with ID, clearly identified a need to provide psychological support for fathers, respond to their emotional needs, and identify mechanisms for coping with stress. Research focused on fathersâ€™ perceptions of their children and of family functioning, therefore, and of their own needs for emotional support, is warranted. Gaining a better understanding of fathersâ€™ perceptions and needs may inform the development of coping mechanisms and more targeted supports for fathers, and thereby improve their health and the well-being of the entire family.Current studyHistorically, fathers of children with ID have been under-researched and under-serviced in China, as elsewhere. Fathers dealing with the stress of raising children with disabilities have only informally organized parent groups to which to turn for emotional support (China Association of Persons with Psychiatric Disability and their Relatives 2014). In order to identify and develop additional strategies to support the emotional needs of fathers, an initial step is to explore fathersâ€™ perceptions of children with ID as well as their perceptions of their familiesâ€™ functioning and of their own needs for emotional support. The research questions addressed in this study are: (1) What are Chinese fathersâ€™ perceptions of their children with ID, and of their familiesâ€™ functioning? (2) To what extent do Chinese fathers of children with ID seek sources of emotional support? (3) What factors might predispose fathers of children with ID to seek sources of emotional support?MethodParticipantsTo recruit participants for this study, I engaged local agencies for disability affairs throughout the 34 provinces of Mainland China to distribute flyers inviting fathers to participate in a national study investigating the health of children with disabilities. The empirical evidence presented here, based on a large sample size from across China, demonstrates that fathers of children with ID tend to have less positive perceptions of their children than do fathers of children with OCHC. 56.1% of fathers of children with ID believe their children are usually or always harder to raise than other children, while only 2.3% of fathers of children with OCHC feel this way. Fathers of children with ID are more likely than fathers of children with OCHC to report that their children often do things that irritate them (36.6% vs.1.7%) and that they more often feel angry towards their children (45.6% vs. 15.3).This is one of only a few studies to use fathersâ€™ perceptions of family functioning to examine overall well-being of families of children with ID. Compared to fathers of children with OCHC, fewer fathers of children with ID believe that the family, when facing problems, would talk together with other family members (63.3% vs. 86.3%), work together to solve their childâ€™s problem (66.0% vs. 88.0%), have strengths to draw on to solve problems (61.5% vs. 90.4%), or stay hopeful in difficult times (66.8% vs. 94.4%). These results indicate that, for fathers of children with ID, family functioning can be problematic. A possible explanation is that distinct challenges associated with ID cause fathers to be overly occupied with their childrenâ€™s maladaptive behaviors (Marsh et al.
2018) and thereby have less time and opportunity to interact with their spouses.When facing problems raising their children with ID or OCHC, fathers tend to rely on family members or friends as primary sources of emotional support. This finding is consistent with earlier studies that show that support providers primarily come from inside the family (Turnbull et al.
2018, Kyzar et al.
2012), as well as with family systems theory and its concept of the closeness and integrity of the family unit. However, only about half (55.6%) the fathers of children with ID would seek emotional support at all. As well, the number of emotional support resources used differed between fathers of children with ID and fathers of children with OCHC. Interestingly, disparity also exists based on the childâ€™s ethnicity (ORâ€‰=â€‰2.94) and fatherâ€™s educational background (ORâ€‰=â€‰16.82).This study is the first to provide empirical evidence that Chinese fathers of children with ID do not willingly seek outside emotional support. A recent national report on family needs of children with autism also showed that, compared to mothers, fathers feel hesitant to speak about their needs and hesitant to seek support from outside the family (China Association of Persons with Psychiatric Disability and their Relatives 2014). One explanation might be that emotional support has long been regarded as an informal type of support that, in traditional Chinese culture, comes from within a family unit. Thus, Chinese fathers would be unlikely even to consider going outside the family to seek emotional support and would rarely seek it from sources such as psychological counseling, parent organizations, or other family support groups. This study is also the first to identify factors that predispose fathers in China to seek emotional support. Ethnicity and educational background clearly play a role.This study did not explore fathersâ€™ coping strategies or ability to get access to social support. A literature review of fathers of children with ID (Davys et al.
2017) suggests that fathers are more likely to seek support in the form of information or to seek social services that support their children rather than to seek emotional support for themselves. Future studies should identify coping strategies and other family supports that fathers might draw upon to assist them in caring for a child with ID.Several limitations to this study are worth mentioning. The paucity of validated data collection tools and the limited number of items available for use in the surveys constrained the depth of information that could be collected and the depth of the individual perspectives that could be obtained. Additional observable survey items might improve the measureâ€™s content validity, and more advanced analysis at the factor/construct level might reveal additional insights. Although logistic regression analyses indicate that fathersâ€™ predisposition to seeking sources of emotional support significantly differs based on ethnicity and educational background, the large confidence interval that includes the null value of one indicates that this result should perhaps be considered inconclusive. Finally, this study does not identify the type of supports fathers need or would value, nor does it compare the perceptions of fathers of children with ID with the perceptions of fathers of typically developing children or with mothers of children with ID. Future studies should address these issues in order to provide broader insights on policymaking as well as on disability-related services and practices.ImplicationsSeveral important implications can be derived from the study. First, efforts should be devoted to identifying adaptive strategies that support Chinese fathersâ€™ positive perceptions of their children with ID, and of their families. Increased awareness of the strengths and needs of their children with ID and of support services available to children and their families might encourage fathers to access emotional supports and result in more positive perceptions of their children. To this end, government agencies or NGOs representing rural or minority ethnic groups might devote efforts to creating support groups and identifying ways to assist fathers to connect with each other or with professionals or other service providers. Second, because Chinese fathers of children with ID are not strongly inclined to seek emotional support at all, especially those from rural areas and those with low educational background, targeted supports that can address their particular emotional needs and expand their social networking is likely to prove worthwhile (Davys et al.
2017 ). These supports might include parent support groups, counseling, and mental health services. Moreover, family support services should be made available within all communities, should use multiple means to reach out to, connect with, and support fathers, and should help fathers realize the potential benefits of emotional support in promoting their own physical and psychological wellbeing. Finally, because those fathers of children with ID who do seek support tend to seek it through several different sources, service providers should ensure that multiple sources of support are available.Further research should also address the quality of support available to fathers, not just the number of supports. It is not clear whether Chinese fathers of children with ID who seek multiple sources of support do so because they need and want multiple sources or because they do not receive sufficient or satisfactory support from those services already available to them. Identifying the types of support or support strategies that Chinese fatherâ€™s need or might value would better inform Chinese service providers in designing, developing, and delivering support to fathers. Addressing fathersâ€™ unique needs with preferred support strategies could facilitate targeted support that would better promote overall family functioning in China.In summary: This study is the first to report a large-scale investigation of fathersâ€™ perceptions of children with ID, their perceptions of family functioning, and their perceptions of their own needs for emotional support. The findings indicate that Chinese fathers of children with ID could benefit from various sources of emotional support to help them deal with the stress of caring for a child with ID. As members of the family unit, fathersâ€™ well-being and emotional health plays a critical role in promoting overall family functioning. The Basic Law of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China


(Adopted at the First Session of the Eighth National People's Congress on March 31, 1993 and promulgated by Order No.3 of the President of the People's Republic of China on March 31, 1993, and effective as of December 20, 1999)
